posts.cooked:
I hate listening to voice notes. But some of my friends love sending voice notes ‚Äì sometimes to me! In my dreams, there would be a small button below a voice note, which I can tap, and then the message bubble expands and shows the text of this voice note (generated by speech recognition from the audio file).

I know this may be technically challenging, but I would love to have this feature . Is a messenger out there which already offers this functionality?

link_counts.title: Looking for input on how you use voice notes
Ability to block / disallow voice messages
Ability to block / disallow voice messages
Is it possible to voice to text within a message?
Proposal for On-Device Spam Detection Feature Addition to iOS App

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Several, but they do that by sending the message to some cloud AI, somethingI doubt Signal will implement. But doing it locally is very challenging - especially if it has to support multiple languages and unusual accents (consider only the difference between UK-English and Texas-English).
An additional issue would be the vast amount of data used to train the voice to text translation!

posts.name: L
posts.cooked:
Voicepop offers transcription for any messaging app on iOS through a share extension. Unfortunately, this is achieved using server-side processing.

But, at least on iOS, Signal could implement decent transcription completely on-device. iOS has a native speech recognition API that Just Press Record implements. I have tested it with English and German, but it supports many other languages as well. Under good recording conditions, it reliably outputs comprehensible transcripts in near-real-time, without much power draw.

link_counts.title: Voicepop ‚Äì Turn voice messages to text instantly

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Instead of converting speech to text:
Maybe a better solution to your annoyance of receiving voice notes would be if there was a setting in your app ‚Äúdon‚Äôt accept voice notes‚Äù which then prevents people from recording voice notes in one-on-one conversations with you.

But that would mean that the sender client would have to be aware of a setting on the receiver client, to prevent a recording from being made. Technical challenges.

link_counts.title: Ability to block / disallow voice messages

posts.cooked: But that ‚Äúoption‚Äù then becomes something that you are forcing on other people rather than just a preference on your end.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
If I am deaf, and I want to use Signal as a messenger, my conversation partner is indeed forced to write everything as text. (Or I would need a conversion speech to text, which is unreliable and takes a whole lot of processing)

Some people might just want to choose the method of conversation, and that is always an arrangement between both sides of the conversation. If I say audio is not a ‚Äòlanguage‚Äô I can/want to receive, than my chat partner should be made aware of that before he starts speaking to me over audio.

Fair enough, but I would see that as a reason to implement transcription for voice notes rather than to add an option to block them. Of course, if you are unable or just don‚Äôt want to use a certain mode of communication you should talk to your contacts and request such. If they want to communicate with you they should be fine with accommodating if possible. But it shouldn‚Äôt be an automatic ‚Äúsorry this contact has blocked this‚Äù feature.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: The issue seems like it‚Äôd need to support tons of languages which would cause a fair amount of bloat?
Signal wouldn‚Äôt have to install every language pack, just the ones the user selected.

posts.name: L
posts.cooked: On iOS, you do not need to install any language packs. The system uses the same speech recognition models for dictation and Siri, so they come pre-installed.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
There is also a privacy side to this, can we trust the text to speech conversion to not leak content out of Signal? If it is an integral part of iOS and Android, ok, it is as save as the OS itself. But it it requires its own terms and conditions, and if it collects data for any purposes (such as improving the functionality) we may not want to integrate anything into Signal. I have no knowledge of this, so I have no idea if that concern is close to the facts.

But in my mind text to speech is a world apart, with new risks as well.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Aaron Whitehouse
posts.cooked:
I really like sending voice messages with Signal, as it is really convenient to do when I am walking etc. I also think that in many cases it is nicer to communicate that way. However, I often do not like receiving voice messages, particularly when I am in a meeting/call or in a hurry and want to know at a glance whether the message is important or non-urgent before I stop what I am doing and put on headphones etc.

I was reading:

Mozilla Hacks ‚Äì the Web developer blog

DeepSpeech 0.6: Mozilla‚Äôs Speech-to-Text Engine Gets Fast, Lean, and...

The Machine Learning team at Mozilla continues work on DeepSpeech, an automatic speech recognition (ASR) engine which aims to make speech recognition technology and trained models openly available to developers. ...

Est. reading time: 8 minutes

and see that they now have a TensorFlow Lite model that is optimised for mobile and embedded use.

I think it would be a really impressive feature for people who use voice messages if Signal had client-side transcription for received voice messages. It could just do the first x seconds/words and make it clear it was a machine-generated transcription instead of actual text sent by the other person. I‚Äôm no UX designer, but something like this might work:

link_counts.title: DeepSpeech 0.6: Mozilla's Speech-to-Text Engine Gets Fast, Lean, and Ubiquitous - Mozilla Hacks - the Web developer blog

posts.name: Jano360
posts.cooked:
Since we probably don‚Äôt want a cloud/server-based solution, what about a pre-trained neural network?
You can use Tensorflow on iOS, Android and JavaScript and e.g. here (https://github.com/itzikgili/speech-to-text-wavenet) would be a Tensorflow implementation of such a network.
Only for English, but it would be a start.

link_counts.title: GitHub - itzikgili/speech-to-text-wavenet: Speech-to-Text-WaveNet : End-to-end sentence level English speech recognition based on DeepMind's WaveNet and tensorflow

posts.name: Ponytail
posts.cooked:
It will be a great disability feature, great for people with hearing disability and,
Will also be useful where a person don‚Äôt want to play the audio, maybe because they don‚Äôt have their headphones around or because of their surroundings.

In my knowledge there are no other messaging apps which does this, however on Telegram there is a bot for the same purpose. Find the link below.

posts.cooked:
Moxie‚Äôs thoughts in a Twitter thread:

twitter.com

Una üá∫üá¶

@Una
It‚Äôs 2021. I need captions on your short videos because most of my phone hole time is reserved for 1AM browsing in bed next to my sleeping spouse, or on the Subway where I can‚Äôt hear anything anyway. #a11yforall
4:31 AM - 1 Nov 2021 210 22
twitter.com

Marco Mannes

@mmannes
@Una And what about audio messages? It would be nice an option to transcript audio messages inside messenger apps @moxie
5:02 PM - 1 Nov 2021
twitter.com

Moxie Marlinspike

@moxie
@mmannes @Una I‚Äôve been surprised that unencrypted messengers like telegram or fb messenger don‚Äôt do this. Signal currently can‚Äôt because there‚Äôs not consistent access to on-device speech-to-text apis, so it‚Äôd currently require shipping your audio to a remote service
5:12 PM - 1 Nov 2021 1
twitter.com

Marco Mannes

@mmannes
@moxie @Una Fair point. I thought about using a trained AI inside Signal. Few time ago I was helping Mozilla's Common Voice but it is probably to big to ship to devices and too expensive to run inside Signal servers. An option that forbides people to send audio messages to me would work too
5:21 PM - 1 Nov 2021

Moxie Marlinspike

@moxie
@mmannes @Una Can‚Äôt run it on our servers, because we can‚Äôt have access to plaintext either. Both Apple and Google are doing on-device STT at this point, we just need to wait until they make those available to developers
5:38 PM - 1 Nov 2021 1

This would be an acceptable workaround/fall-back for this topic that‚Äôs still unsolved:

Ability to block / disallow voice messages Feature Requests
So what now? Some people are saying ‚Äúit could be difficult to implement‚Äù and that‚Äôs it? Topic is still not solved! Other people may want to be able to opt-out from other features but as I mentioned earlier: There is huge difference between a voice message that can only be listened to and the other examples you brought up. All the other stuff (emoji, sticker, gif, ‚Ä¶) can simply be viewed/read in the same way as a text message.

Somebody created a fork which is capable of transcribing voice messages

a2p.it ‚Äì 29 May 22

CoquiSTT + Signal = Love (death to voice messages)

Let‚Äôs face it: if you‚Äôre reading this, chances are that you are receiving the dreaded voice messages more often than you would want. I like the romantic feeling behind voice messages on Instant Messaging platforms: you can feel the nuances of the...

link_counts.title: CoquiSTT + Signal = Love (death to voice messages) | NOT Dexter's Lab

posts.cooked:
Voice messages are painful to listen to if you are in a hurry (or working, listening to music, in a meeting, ‚Ä¶). Why not add a feature to transcribe voice messages?

I‚Äôd be happy to sketch this out for iOS and implement a first working version.

Edit: My post got moved over here and I just read through it. Again, I‚Äôd be happy to implement it on iOS. How does the process of adding such a feature look like?
On iOS there is SFSpeechRecognizer, but there is probably also a decent TensorFlow Lite model which we can use across all platforms.

posts.name: Alana
posts.cooked:
Automated voice message transcription with OpenAI Whisper?

I‚Äôd be happy to take this on if the Signal team is interested in something like this.

I feel like it‚Äôd be quite helpful to be able to auto-transcribe voice messages.
